0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-bets-idUSKCN11X271	A modest bump for Clinton in online wagering hours after debate	"
By Melissa Fares
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's probability of winning the White House got a modest bump in online betting markets on Tuesday
column2: a day after her debate with Republican Donald Trump.The price for a contract favoring Clinton on the popular PredictIt betting market was up 2 cents from Monday's post-debate closing and implied a 68 percent probability that she would win the Nov. 8 election. Although during the debate Clinton was as high as 70 percent
column3: her Monday night closing of 66 matched the highest closing number since her health took a stumble on Sept. 11. A pro-Trump contract on Tuesday indicated his probability for victory was 34 percent.Trading in both contracts remained brisk on the heels of the first of three debates. PredictIt contracts are priced from 0 to 100 cents
column4: with the contract price equating to a probability a candidate will win the election.

column1: Initially
column2: the price swings for both candidates were the largest since early August
column3: though a substantial portion of Clinton's gain and Trump's fall had been retraced by early afternoon on Tuesday.The swing following the debate put the brakes on a big Trump price rally on PredictIt that coincided with a tightening in most public opinion polls. On PredictIt
column4: the implied probability of him winning had risen to 38 percent heading into the debate from 28 percent at the end of August.

column1: Clinton's prospects also showed comparable improvement on betting sites based in Ireland and the United Kingdom. UK-based Betfair called the debate for Clinton based on odds movements on its platform
column2: where more than 3 million pounds were bet during the event. The implied probability of a Clinton win in November climbed to 69 percent on Betfair
column3: the strongest it has been since her prospects took a hit over her pneumonia diagnosis this month. Trump's probability fell to 30 percent from 37 percent.

column1: On Ireland's PaddyPower
column2: Clinton's odds also had shortened
column3: or improved
column4: to 2-to-5 from 1-to-2 in the early moments of Monday's debate. Trump's odds
column5: which initially lengthened following the debate
column6: had shortened modestly to 2-to-1. (Reporting by Melissa Fares and Angela Moon; Writing by Dan Burns; Editing by Howard Goller)"	['Clinton'
column7: 'Trump']	[]

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-markets-factbox-idUSKCN11X09G	Factbox: Market participants react to U.S. presidential debate	"

Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump traded barbs and accusations on Monday in the first debate ahead of the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election.Following is a compilation of reaction to the debate from investors
column2: economists and financial market analysts:FACTBOX: Swing states that may determine the election: reut.rs/1UhE642MORE COVERAGE: cpurl://apps.cp./cms/?pageId=us-2016JAMES ATHEY
column3: INVESTMENT MANAGER AT ABERDEEN ASSET MANAGEMENT:

column1: What we're seeing in markets this morning is a small
column2: collective sigh of relief because most commentators
column3: and the few polls that have been released
column4: suggest Clinton won the debate. Equities have undone much of yesterday's weakness and key Trump indicators such as the Mexican peso and Canadian dollar have rallied. This supports the notion once again that Trump is seen as protectionist and anti-globalization.""The reality is that these moves are all fairly insignificant. Polls on voting intentions still show that the race is essentially neck and neck. It will be these polls which truly have the power to drive a genuine re-pricing.""MICHAEL METCALFE
column5: HEAD OF GLOBAL MACRO STRATEGY AT STATE STREET GLOBAL MARKETS
column6: LONDON:

column1: In a similar way that sterling became the market proxy for Brexit risk
column2: so moves in the Mexican peso and expected volatility of the Mexican peso appear to have become the main market proxy for expressing the probability of a Trump presidency. ""While there are many weeks of the campaign to run
column3: the market reaction to the first debate does not mean that volatility will dissipate
column4: but it does suggest Trump's recent momentum has been arrested.""""The recent narrowing in the polls means that markets have had to discount more uncertainty
column5: and one debate will not settle that.""KIT JUCKES

column3: the South African rand and the Korean won all won
column4: while the Japanese yen was the loser.""JACK ABLIN
column5: CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER AT BMO PRIVATE BANK IN CHICAGO:

I believe that investors pricing in the odds of either candidate winning. Modest positive moves suggest the Clinton campaign both managed expectations and delivered on beating them. The fear for investors was that she would either have some physical issue
column2: look weak or have an excuse for one or both. She looked sharp
column3: on point and clearly delivered on a message and style that reassured markets.""BRIAN BATTLE

Don't forget in the middle of this we also had some numbers showing slightly better growth than previously expected and that also helped the last 5 points or so in the futures rally.""After a weak day some of this may just be people covering their risk overnight.""

Each will appeal to different sets of voters. A good example of Trump's emotional

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-asia-idUSKCN11X0YT	Asian viewers give nod to Clinton after first presidential debate	"
By Michael Martina and Nobuhiro Kubo
| BEIJING/TOKYO
BEIJING/TOKYO Hillary Clinton put Donald Trump on the defensive and showed a better grasp of foreign policy issues
column2: according to a sampling of people across Asia who watched the fiery first U.S. presidential debate.    In China
column3: the debate was streamed live on China's Twitter-like Weibo service and attracted thousands of comments despite the lack of a translation into Chinese. Some called Trump ""a loose cannon""
column4: while others thought that as a businessman he was best qualified to lead the world's largest economy. William Hua
column5: a Chinese lawyer who watched the debate at an American Chamber of Commerce event in Beijing
column6: said he thought Clinton came out on top.He was most concerned
column7: though
column8: about an issue that didn't come up in the debate. ""Donald Trump says Japan and South Korea can develop nuclear weapons? It seems absolutely ridiculous
column9: Hua said. Trump said in an interview with The New York Times in March he would consider letting Japan and South Korea build their own nuclear weapons
column10: rather than rely on America for protection against North Korea. Opinion polls have shown the two candidates in a tight race leading up to the debate.A CNN poll of debate watchers released after the event found 62 percent felt Clinton won compared to 27 percent for Trump.  In a sign investors also saw Clinton as the winner
column11: U.S. S&P500 stock futures rose as did Asian shares. ""Markets started to call the debate for Hillary within the first 15 minutes or so
column12: with the Mexican peso surging in what is probably its busiest Asian session in years
column14: a senior currency analyst at Westpac in Sydney. The Mexican currency has risen and fallen in recent weeks depending on polling numbers for Trump
column15: who has vowed to take trade protectionist measure against the United States' southern neighbor and build a wall across the U.S. border with Mexico to prevent illegal immigration.

column1: CHINA BASHING
Trump raised eyebrows among a packed crowd watching the debate at The American Club in Singapore when he lashed out against China. ""Look at what China is doing to our country
column2: Trump said not long after the debate began. ""They are devaluing their currency and we have nobody in our government to fight them ... They are using our country as a piggy bank to rebuild China
column3: and many other countries are doing the same thing.""Landy Eng
column4: a former employee of the California state government who's been living in Singapore the past 20 years
column5: said he was an undecided voter. ""But Trump's China-bashing is something I'm not particularly in favor of
column6: he said. Still
column7: Eng said he does like the  ""disruptive"" factor of Trump's campaign and thinks it is making Clinton a better candidate.Aloysius Lee
column8: a 65-year-old retiree from Hong Kong
column9: who watched the debate at The Foreign Correspondents' Club in the territory
column10: said that Trump was too unpredictable.

column1: Hillary is the kind of person you can do business with
column2: at least from my point of view
column3: Lee said. With Trump
column4: ""you don't know what's going to happen next
column5: you don't know what he's going to say next"".NORTH ASIA ALLIANCES

column1: South Koreans
column2: watching the debate on TV screens in the lobby of Seoul's central train station
column3: said they were with Clinton on the issues. ""Trump has ideas of withdrawing U.S. forces from our country
column4: and in terms of national security
column5: Trump is a threatening figure
column6: said Lee Hyo-jin
column7: 26. ""So I support Hillary
column8: she said.Trump during the debate again said if U.S. allies like Japan and South Korea ""don't pay their fair share
column9: they may have to defend themselves or help us out.""

column1: Asked about Trump's comment
column2: Japan's Defence Minister Tomomi Inada told a regularly scheduled news conference on Tuesday the U.S.-Japan military alliance does not just benefit Japan ""but is also in the interests of the United States."" Clinton seemed to have the better temperament during the debate
column3: according to some Asian viewers. Li Jiaoli
column5: an editing intern from China's southwestern province of Sichuan
column6: said Clinton seemed more presidential while Trump's expressions made her laugh. ""Trump's responses were too aggressive. High-level politicians should have more self-control
column7: Li said.DEBATE OPTICS

column1: The debate prompted a storm of tweets around the region
column2: many of them commenting on the optics of the debate.""Trump is looking worked up and angry and sulky and shouty -She looks utterly in control by contrast
column3: said Barkha Dutt
column4: news anchor on India's NDTV in a tweet. ""She ignores his barbs & attacks; he gets baited by every one of hers."" Mel Fryer
column6: a waitress at the Mercantile Hotel in Sydney's historic Rocks district said she was ""terrified"" at the prospect of a Trump presidency
column7: while the debate screened to an empty pub. ""But he's going ok
column8: she said of his debate performance. ""He uses simple words and simple phrases and gets his point across."" (Additional reporting by Venus Wu and Hera Poon in Hong Kong
column9: Tom Westbrook in Sydney and Doug Busvine in Sydney. Writing by Bill Tarrant.)"	['Clinton'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-sniffles-idUSKCN11X0EV	Trump's debate sniffs take off on social media	"
By Angela Moon
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Republican White House candidate Donald Trump stole the social media spotlight during Monday night's U.S. presidential debate on at least one count - what Twitter users branded his #Trumpsniffle. The wealthy businessman sniffed repeatedly as he faced off against Democratic rival Hillary Clinton in their first debate
column2: giving rise to the hashtag and a surge of interest on social media what might be causing his nose to run. Parody accounts
column3: Donald's Sinuses (@TrumpsSinuses) and Trump sniff (@TrumpSniff)
column4: gained a large following.Trump
column6: told Fox News on Tuesday morning he did not have a cold. ""No
column7: no sniffles
column8: no
column9: he said. ""No cold."" He complained he had a faulty microphone and joked that maybe it was picking up breathing.Several tweeters seized on the sniffling to hit back at Trump over his repeated digs at the health and stamina of Clinton
column11: who had pneumonia earlier this month.

column1: Overall
column2: Twitter said the debate
column3: the first in a series ahead of the Nov. 8 election
column4: was the most tweeted-about political event in the social media company's history. Trump was the focus of 62 percent of the conversation on the social media platform
column5: Twitter said.On Facebook
column6: conversations about Trump made up 79 percent of debate chat
column7: while Clinton's share of the conversation was 21 percent.

column1: However
column2: sentiment appeared to go Clinton's way. Social media analytics firm Zoomph said tweets mentioning Clinton ended at a ratio of about 1.5 to 1
column3: which meant that for every negative mention
column4: there were 1.5 positive mentions
column5: Zoomph said.Sentiment toward Trump fluctuated
column6: but ended nearly flat at a ratio of one positive mention to every negative one.

column1: The most tweeted-about topics were the economy
column2: foreign affairs
column3: energy and the environment
column4: terrorism and guns. (Reporting by Angela Moon; Editing by Howard Goller and Frances Kerry)"	['Clinton'
column5: 'Trump']	['guns']

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-analysis-idUSKCN11X0G4	In first face-off with Clinton
column2: Trump struggles to be 'change' candidate	"

column1: By James Oliphant
| HEMPSTEAD
column2: New York

column1: HEMPSTEAD
column2: New York Running as an anti-establishment candidate
column3: Donald Trump took the presidential debate stage on Monday night to hammer home his call for sweeping political change and try to win over millions of undecided voters. But the Republican nominee seemed unable to capitalize on his opportunity in front of a television audience that by some estimates may have been 100-million strong. Instead of presenting himself as a change agent
column4: he spent most of the evening trading personal insults with his Democratic opponent
column5: Hillary Clinton.It illustrated the paradox that has plagued Trump's campaign. Polls show an electorate hungry for change
column6: with a majority believing the country is on the wrong track. Yet Trump's brash personality and his tendency to stir up controversy have made him
column7: at times
column8: a poor messenger. Trump started strongly on Monday
column9: sticking to the bread and butter theme of his campaign - the erosion of U.S. manufacturing jobs. But he soon lost his composure
column10: especially when Clinton questioned his success in business and his refusal to release his tax returns and accused him of racism and sexism. When on message Trump paints a bleak picture of a United States that is victimized by China in trade
column11: hemorrhaging jobs to Mexico and blighted by gangs of illegal immigrants roaming the streets of ""warzone"" inner cities committing crimes. Robert Adams
column15: said he thought Trump's dystopian view of America was correct. ""I think it's hell in the big cities
column16: Adams said.But after watching the debate
column17: he viewed both the real estate magnate and Clinton as a ""sad"" choice for American voters and was leaning toward Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson.

column1: Reuters/Ipsos polling shows an electorate in a downcast mood
column2: with 64 percent of Americans believing the country is on the wrong track. That number includes 87 percent of Republicans and 44 percent of Democrats.When Reuters asked voters to pick the first word that comes to mind when thinking about the country
column3: the most popular choice was ""frustration
column4: followed by ""fear"" and ""anger."" Some of Trump's strongest moments at Monday's debate were when he categorized Clinton
column5: a former secretary of state and U.S. senator as a ""typical politician
column6: accusing her of achieving nothing in her years in Congress and government.

column1: With an electorate yearning for change
column2: Clinton is hamstrung by her long record and her close association with the Obama administration. Rather than proposing wholesale political overhaul
column3: Clinton  offers up a vision of a country headed in the right direction but one that needs some changes to address income inequality and create jobs. Her more optimistic view impressed another undecided voter
column4: Nancy Willhite
column6: of Portland
column7: Oregon. ""She seems more in touch with reality to me
column8: she said. A Reuters/Ipsos poll published on Monday found that about half of all likely voters in the United States were looking to the debate to help them make a final decision.

column1: Ron Bonjean
column2: a Republican strategist in Washington
column3: said Trump's performance on Monday would have left many undecided voters with questions about his ability to lead the country.""Donald Trump has to convince them that he is going to be a safe alternative and I think it's open to debate whether he pulled that off
column4: Bonjean said. Christopher Devine
column5: a political science professor at the University of Dayton in Ohio said Trump's message on Monday sometimes got lost in a welter of hyperbole that invited mocking responses from Clinton. ""He'll identify a problem people are concerned about
column6: but in that excitement over making that point
column7: he goes overboard and makes claims that don't hold up. It loses its effectiveness at that point."" (Reporting by James Oliphant
column8: Ginger Gibson
column9: and Chris Kahn. Editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"	['Obama'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-bets-idUSKCN11X09O	Clinton gains in online betting markets after U.S. presidential debate	"
By Angela Moon
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK U.S. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's probability of winning the White House gained in online betting markets following the first debate of the campaign on Monday night between her and Republican Donald Trump.A Clinton contract on the popular PredictIt betting market gained 6 cents from the previous day's level to 69 cents
column2: while a contract favoring Donald Trump's prospects for victory tumbled 7 cents to 31 cents. Contracts are priced from 0 cents to 100 cents
column3: with the contract price equating to a probability of whether that candidate will win the Nov. 8 election.The price swings for both candidates were the largest since early August
column4: and placed Clinton's lead in that market at the widest in about two weeks.

column1: Clinton's prospects also improved on the Irish betting site Paddy Power. About halfway through Monday's debate
column2: she was shown as a 1-to-2 favorite
column3: and those odds shortened to 4-to-9 in the moments after the debate ended. Trump's odds lengthened to 23-to-10 from 9-to-4.

column1: The swing following the debate put the brakes on a big Trump price rally on PredictIt that coincided with a tightening in most public opinion polls. The implied probability of him winning had risen to 38 cents on Sunday from just 28 cents at the end of August. Bets on Trump fell as low as 5 cents on February but went up as high as 44 cents in May. Bets on Clinton
column2: the persistent favorite in most wagering markets
column3: went as low as 37 cents in January and as high as 79 cents in August.

column1: The debate on Monday was the first of three scheduled face-offs between the two candidates before the Nov. 8 election. (Reporting by Angela Moon; Writing by Dan Burns; Editing by Peter Cooney)"	['Clinton'
column2: 'Trump']	[]

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-nuclear-future-idUSKCN11W2IW	Cost of modernizing U.S. nuclear weapons to fall to next president	"
By Yeganeh Torbati
| MINOT AIR FORCE BASE
column2: N.D.

column1: MINOT AIR FORCE BASE
column2: N.D. In this flat
column3: windy expanse just south of the Canadian border
column4: U.S. Air Force pilots fly the same bombers their grandfathers flew
column5: using mid-20th century cables and pulleys.Each spring
column6: the airmen and airwomen must clear melting snow from the steel and concrete doors of the silos that house 150 nuclear-tipped ballistic missiles scattered across thousands of square miles of the upper Great Plains.The U.S. nuclear arsenal
column7: patched
column8: welded
column10: was built between 25 and 62 years ago when the United States found itself locked in an arms race with a rival superpower
column12: its future is an issue in the campaign for the Nov. 8 presidential election.Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton has said she would call for a nuclear posture review
column14: as one of her first acts upon taking office. Republican candidate Donald Trump has said he would be open to reversing decades of U.S. policy and allowing allies such as Japan and South Korea to acquire their own nuclear weapons to deter a strike from North Korea
column15: which carried out its fifth and largest nuclear test this month.On Monday
column16: in his first visit to Minot Air Force Base in North Dakota as U.S. Secretary of Defense
column17: Ash Carter said America's nuclear deterrence was the ""bedrock"" of its security
column18: and the Pentagon's No. 1 priority.""If we don't replace these systems
column19: quite simply they will age even more
column24: speaking at a lectern in front of a B-52 bomber loaded with cruise missiles.""The fact is
column25: most of our nuclear weapon delivery systems have already been extended decades beyond their original expected service lives. So it's not a choice between replacing these platforms or keeping them - it's really a choice between replacing them or losing them
column28: had built new nuclear weapons systems
column29: raising questions as to whether its leaders were cautious enough when it came to atomic weapons. And North Korea presents a sustained threat
column30: Carter said.Carter's speech coincides with a growing realization among defense officials and experts that budget constraints almost certainly will force the next president to decide whether and how quickly to proceed with the Obama administration's plans to maintain and modernize the U.S. nuclear arsenal.

column1: CRUNCH TIME
The crunch comes in the next decade as American ballistic missile submarines
column2: bombers
column3: and land-based missiles - the three legs of the nuclear triad - reach the end of their useful lives.The Congressional Budget Office estimates the total cost of nuclear forces through 2024 at $348 billion
column4: but that does not include some of the costliest upgrades
column5: scheduled for the latter half of the next decade. Independent estimates have put the cost of maintaining and modernizing the arsenal at about $1 trillion dollars over 30 years.""There's a bipartisan commitment to doing that upgrade
column6: so we have to assume those funds will come through
column7: Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz told Reuters on Sept. 20. ""But it will be a significant budget increase
column8: especially in the next decade.""The Energy Department shares responsibility with the Pentagon for the nuclear arsenal
column9: and some of its research and production facilities are 73 years old.The next administration could abandon or delay some aspects of modernization to cut costs. Or it could raise taxes
column12: all unpopular steps with American voters.

column1: The most vulnerable elements of the modernization plans are a long-range standoff weapon
column2: or LRSO - a nuclear-capable cruise missile launched from an aircraft - and new land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs).Ten U.S. senators
column3: including Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bernie Sanders of Vermont
column4: called on President Barack Obama in July to cancel the LRSO
column5: saying it ""would provide an unnecessary capability that could increase the risk of nuclear war.""Some Pentagon officials and defense experts have said the cruise missile would be a hedge against improved air defenses that are difficult for even a stealthy bomber to penetrate.A Clinton or Trump administration also could cut the number of land-based ballistic missiles below the 400 currently planned or delay a new missile by extending the life of the current Minuteman IIIs
column6: which each carry a warhead with an explosive yield of at least 300 kilotons
column7: 20 times more powerful than the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima
column8: which killed an estimated 140
column9: 000 people. The United States is one of five nuclear weapons states allowed to keep a nuclear arsenal under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The others are Russia

column1: The U.S. Air Force has estimated the cost of a new ground-based system - including missiles
column2: command-and-control systems and launch control centers - to be more than $60 billion.    Some former U.S. officials
column3: including former defense secretary William Perry
column4: have argued that land-based missiles are not essential and should be phased out; proponents say they are more important in the face of potential nuclear threats by Russia and North Korea.Much of the planned modernization is nearly locked in  because of the need for new weapons and because some of it is so far along
column5: said Evan Montgomery
column6: a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments
column7: a Washington-based research group.The B-21 long-range strike bomber and the replacement for the Navy's 14 Ohio-class ballistic missile submarines are ""the two most expensive items
column8: and they're arguably the two safest in a lot of ways
column9: Montgomery said. The bomber can deliver both conventional and nuclear weapons
column10: and the submarine is considered a priority because it would survive any first strike by an adversary.The Navy plans to replace its Ohio-class submarines
column11: first commissioned in 1981 and armed with up to 24 Trident missiles with multiple independently targeted warheads
column12: with 12 boats costing about $100 billion.In his speech on Monday
column13: Carter said that most people do not realize that spending on the nuclear program is a small percentage of total defense spending. At its peak
column14: nuclear spending would make up about five percent of the Pentagon's budget
column15: which is now around $600 billion annually
column17: the funding gap means that despite the Pentagon's massive budget
column18: the next president will face an unavoidable dilemma.""There's no doubt in my mind that we're tens of billions of dollars short in that time frame from what it takes to execute a global strategy
column20: a former undersecretary of defense for policy in the Obama administration. ""It's not a rounding error anymore."" (Reporting by Yeganeh Torbati; additional reporting by Timothy Gardner; Editing by John Walcott and Grant McCool)"	['Sanders'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-pipeline-nativeamericans-idUSKCN11W0Y6	Obama avoids pipeline comment but urges tribal sovereignty	"
By Valerie Volcovici and Julia Harte
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama on Monday avoided direct mention of a pipeline that has provoked high-profile protests from Native Americans but urged tribal leaders to use the spotlight to continue pushing for recognition even after he leaves office.Obama spoke at his eighth and final Tribal Nations Conference
column2: which he created during his first year in office. Leaders of more than 560 Native American tribes gathered for the Washington event as one of the largest Native American protests in decades continues in North Dakota.In his remarks
column3: Obama acknowledged that Native American tribes have unified around the demonstrations led by the Standing Rock Sioux
column4: a tribe that he visited in 2014.  ""I know that many of you have come together across tribes and across the country to support the community at Standing Rock and together you are making your voices heard
column5: he said. ""This moment highlights why it's so important that we redouble our efforts to make sure that every federal agency truly consults and listens and works with you
column6: sovereign to sovereign.""In recent weeks
column7: protests against the Dakota Access pipeline have drawn international attention
column8: prompting the U.S. government to temporarily block its construction on federal land. Tribal leaders say the pipeline will desecrate sacred land and pollute water.When fully connected to existing lines
column11: 770 km) pipeline would be the first to carry crude oil from the Bakken shale directly to the U.S. Gulf. The $3.7 billion project is being built by the Dakota Access subsidiary of Dallas-based Energy Transfer Partners LP.Obama discussed the progress made by his administration over the last eight years to improve relations with tribal nations
column12: and urged leaders to keep fighting for more visibility and input regardless of who succeeds him in the White House next year.""Our progress depends in part on who sits the in Oval Office
column13: and whether they're setting the right priorities
column14: but lasting progress depends on all of us
column15: not just who the president is.""

column1: Various Obama administration officials unveiled initiatives aimed at upholding Native American sovereignty at the conference.Interior Secretary Sally Jewell announced a forthcoming memorandum from Obama that would require federal agencies to consider Native American treaty rights in decision-making on natural resource projects
column2: hoping to avoid future conflicts with tribes such as the current Dakota Access dispute.The Justice and Interior Departments also announced  settlements with 17 tribes that had sued the U.S. government
column3: accusing them of mismanaging monetary assets and natural resources that the government held in trust for the tribes. The ""vast majority"" of all such disputes have been settled
column4: according to the government
column5: which has paid $1.9 billion to resolve the cases since April 2012.

column1: Those settlements characterize the Obama administration's effort to mend ties ""where we have failed in the past in our trust responsibilities
column2: said Lawrence Roberts
column3: assistant secretary for Indian Affairs at the Interior Department
column4: on the sidelines of Monday's conference.Regan Dunn
column6: a member of the Standing Rock Sioux tribe
column7: delivered opening remarks at the conference. Dunn said afterward she had never imagined a company might try to build a pipeline through her homeland
column8: but that the wide opposition among various tribes - including some she had not previously heard of - has been ""heartwarming.""Brian Cladoosby
column9: president of the National Congress of American Indians
column11: praised Obama's legacy on Native American issues and warned the assembly that ""there is no guarantee going forward there will be the same commitment from the next administration.""

column1: When the Justice Department
column2: Interior Department and the U.S. Army temporarily blocked the pipeline's construction on Sept. 9
column3: the administration called for ""a serious discussion"" about how tribes are consulted by the government on decisions over major infrastructure projects. The Army
column4: Interior and Justice departments will hold hearings on the shortcomings of the present process on Oct. 11
column5: and formal discussions with tribes in six U.S. regions from Oct. 25 through Nov. 21. The deadline for written comments will be Nov. 30
column6: the agencies announced.On Thursday
column7: the chairman of the Standing Rock Sioux tribe
column8: Dave Archambault
column9: told a House of Representatives panel there was no ""meaningful consultation"" before permits were issued to bring the pipeline through his tribe's territory.Archambault is scheduled to speak on Monday evening at a rally of pipeline opponents. (Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe and Matthew Lewis)"	['Obama'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-pipeline-nativeamericans-interven-idUSKCN11W0B2	From prairie to the White House: Inside a Tribe's quest to stop a pipeline	"
By Ernest Scheyder and Valerie Volcovici
| CANNON BALL
column2: N.D./WASHINGTON

column1: CANNON BALL
column2: N.D./WASHINGTON Three days after guard dogs attacked Native Americans protesting an oil pipeline project in North Dakota in early September
column3: an unprecedented event took place at the White House.Brian Cladoosby
column4: president of the National Congress of American Indians
column5: which represents more than 500 tribes
column6: spoke to nearly a dozen of President Barack Obama's Cabinet-level advisers at a September 6 meeting of the White House's three-year-old Native American Affairs Council. It was the first time a tribal leader addressed a session of the council
column7: and Cladoosby was invited in his role as the Indian Congress' leader.Cladoosby
column8: a Swinomish Indian from Washington state
column9: spoke twice at the one-hour roundtable. He told Reuters he praised the Obama administration in his opening statement for its track record on Native American issues such as pushing to reform the Indian Health Service.But when Cladoosby gave his closing speech
column10: he delivered an impassioned request to his audience: stand with Native Americans who have united with the Standing Rock Sioux tribe and block construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline
column12: 100 mile conduit to get oil from North Dakota to Illinois. That plea marked one of the previously unreported turning points in a drama that played out since February and culminated September 9 with an about face by the U.S. government
column13: from giving the pipeline a green light to backing a request from North Dakota's Standing Rock Sioux to halt construction of the pipeline. The tribe fears sacred sites could be destroyed during the line's construction and that a future oil spill would pollute its drinking water.This month's win for the tribe
column14: which could be reversed by regulators
column15: is a rare instance of protests resulting in quick federal action and the triumph of an unusual alliance between environmentalists and Native Americans
column16: who both say they were emboldened by the defeat of the Keystone XL pipeline last fall.It also was the most galvanizing movement in Native American politics in decades
column20: Sioux and other traditional rivals united to fight what they considered an assault on their way of life.Cladoosby did not play a high-profile role in the early days of the pipeline controversy. But that day he spoke to a high echelon of power
column21: including Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell
column22: White House Domestic Policy Council director Cecilia Munoz
column23: and the heads of the Departments of Energy; Agriculture; Education; Health and Human Services; and the Environmental Protection Agency
column24: according to a senior administration official who asked not to be named and to a photo of attendees seen by Reuters.""The world is watching
column25: he said in prepared remarks shared with Reuters.A few days earlier
column26: video of pipeline security personnel in North Dakota armed with guard dogs and mace trying to disperse protesters went viral on social media.One of the first videos was taken and posted on Facebook by Lonnie Favel
column27: a member of Utah's Ute tribe who traveled to North Dakota to support the protests.""I was getting messages of support from New Zealand
column31: Obama had not weighed in on the Dakota dispute even though he personally had visited  the Standing Rock in June 2014.Just a day after Cladoosby issued his plea to administration officials
column32: Obama attended a young leaders conference in Laos where a Malaysian woman asked him about the Dakota Access pipeline and how he could ensure a clean water supply and protect ancestral land.Obama said he needed to ask his staff for more information
column33: but touted his track record protecting Native Americans' ""ancestral lands
column37: ""this is something that I hope will continue as we go forward.""

column1: A FATEFUL DECISION
In late 2014
column2: pipeline operator Energy Transfer Partners made a fateful decision.Dallas-based ETP chose to route its proposed Dakota Access pipeline away from North Dakota's capital
column3: Bismarck
column4: and southward within half a mile of the Standing Rock Sioux tribe's reservation.Part of its rationale
column5: laid out in a report for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
column6: which regulates infrastructure projects that traverse certain inland waterways
column7: was that the route would avoid Bismarck and thus pose no threat to the city's water supply. The Bismarck route also is more populated and thus would require more easements from multiple landowners. Ironically
column8: that 139-page report concluded the Standing Rock route would raise ""no environmental justice issues"" because the pipeline would not cross tribal lands.The Army Corps' decision angered environmental activists and unwittingly introduced a powerful new element into the environmental movement: Indian rights groups
column9: who quickly tapped into an extensive network of green activists forged during five long years of protests against TransCanada's Keystone XL pipeline
column10: which Obama formally nixed last November.CAMPAIGN GAINS STEAM

column1: The protest gained steam in February when Standing Rock Sioux leaders asked for legal help from Earthjustice
column2: an environmental law group that had previously helped U.S. tribes and Canadian First Nations fight Kinder Morgan's Trans Mountain pipeline
column3: according to Jan Hasselman
column4: an attorney from Earthjustice working on the North Dakota case
column5: and tribal leaders.

column1: Two months later
column2: about 18 tribe members started praying daily near the pipeline's planned route in North Dakota. The participants would grow in size
column3: creating a group called the Sacred Stone Camp.The international environmental movement soon took notice
column4: including
column5: 350.org
column6: an environmentalist group that helped defeat the Keystone XL pipeline. In July
column7: the group sent a delegation to the Sacred Stone Camp to see how they could help.In many ways
column8: the Dakota Access pipeline drew its inspiration from the fight to stop the Keystone XL pipeline
column9: according to organizers from 350 and other environmental groups.""We didn't have to totally reinvent the wheel
column11: a progressive advocacy group.By then the Sacred Stone Camp
column12: located alongside the confluence of the Cannon Ball and Missouri rivers about an hour south of Bismarck
column13: had swollen in size to thousands
column14: forming a de facto town of  tents
column19: horse corrals and a legal clinic.The tribal members and environmentalists agreed to seize on the U.S. Army Corps' ""fast-tracking"" of permits for the pipeline in late July
column20: which they argued was illegal and a violation of tribal rights
column22: the Corps had the right to approve pipelines in general and consider specific local concerns
column24: if appropriate. The Corps said it effectively considered its due diligence requirement met when it green lit the line in July. Later that same month
column25: the tribe filed suit against the Army Corps in federal court.

column1: INTERNAL RIFT
While the government's reversal in September caught most by surprise
column2: a March 29 letter from the Department of the Interior to the Army Corps reviewed by Reuters shows that disagreements within the administration had been percolating for months.The Interior department
column3: which is responsible for protecting Native Americans' welfare
column4: said the Army Corps ""did not adequately justify or otherwise support its conclusion that there would be no significant impacts upon the surrounding environment and community"" from the pipeline.Energy Transfer
column5: the Department of Justice
column6: the Army Corps and the Department of the Interior did not respond to requests for comment.The letter presaged the intra-government fighting ahead of the White House's decision to temporarily block the line.The federal delay of the pipeline ""isn't something that just fell out of the sky
column7: Archambault
column8: the tribe's chairman
column9: said in an interview. ""We feed (federal regulators) information all the time on everything that's illegal here.""Archambault declined to discuss responses from federal regulators he received.On September 9
column10: just three days after Cladoosby made his plea at the White House
column11: U.S. District Judge James Boasberg rejected a request from the tribe to block the $3.7 billion project.Minutes after that ruling
column14: suspended construction on a two-mile stretch of federal land below the Missouri River.White House spokesman Josh Earnest said federal regulators
column15: who could still ultimately approve the project
column16: called the pause to make sure the concerns of all parties were taken into account. James Gette
column17: a senior official in the environment and natural resources division of the DOJ
column18: noted in a September 16 hearing that construction was halted mainly because the Dakota Access pipeline didn't have an easement for the area where the tribe gets its drinking water.Protesters have vowed not to leave their camp until the pipeline is scrapped or moved far away from their reservation. Their concerns about potential spills
column20: have precedent.An analysis of government data by Reuters shows that Sunoco Logistics
column21: the future operator of the pipeline and a unit of ETP
column22: has had the highest rate of spills since 2010 than any of its competitors. Sunoco told Reuters it has taken measures to reduce its spill rate.Cladoosby admits he ""was really surprised"" by the fast moving events after his strategically-timed entreaty.He will be back at the White House on Monday and Tuesday. Leaders of 567 native American tribes will meet with Obama in Washington to tackle a range of issues facing Native Americans from economic development to environmental protection - including the Dakota Access pipeline.(This version of the story corrects the first name of White House Domestic Policy Council director to Cecilia
column23: not Celia in paragraph 10) (Additional reporting by Mica Rosenberg
column25: Julia Harte and Timothy Gardner; Writing By Terry Wade and Ernest Scheyder; editing by Eric Effron and Edward Tobin)"	['Nelson'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-yahoo-cyber-congress-idUSKCN11W1VM	U.S. senator seeks SEC probe of Yahoo disclosure on hacking	"
By Dustin Volz and Jim Finkle
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Democratic Senator Mark Warner on Monday asked the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate whether Yahoo (YHOO.O) and its senior executives fulfilled obligations to inform investors and the public about a hacking attack affecting 500 million user accounts.""Disclosure is the foundation of federal securities laws
column2: and public companies are required to disclose material events that shareholders should know about
column3: Warner said in a letter to SEC Chairwoman Mary Jo White.Yahoo has faced pointed questions about exactly when it knew about the 2014 cyber attack announced last week that exposed the email credentials of half a billion accounts
column4: a critical issue for the company as it seeks to prevent the breach from affecting a pending takeover of its core business by Verizon Inc (VZ.N).Warner also asked the SEC to probe whether Yahoo has ""made complete and accurate representations"" about the security of its information technology systems
column5: and for the agency to evaluate its current thresholds for how and when companies need to report a material data breach.Although the SEC has longstanding guidance on when publicly traded companies should report hacking incidents
column6: companies that have experienced known breaches often omit those details in regulatory filings
column7: according to a 2012 Reuters investigation.(reut.rs/2dblx5S)

column1: In a Sept. 9 regulatory filing with the SEC
column2: Yahoo stated it did not have knowledge of ""any incidents of
column3: or third party claims alleging ... unauthorized access"" of personal data of its customers that could have a material adverse effect on Verizon's acquisition.Establishing that Yahoo is liable for damages under SEC rules is a ""pretty high bar"" in data breach cases
column4: said Robert Cattanach
column5: a lawyer at Dorsey & Whitney who specializes in cyber security.

column1: Yahoo is additionally protected from liability given the relative lack of sensitivity of the data compromised
column2: Cattanach said
column3: though he said both the SEC and Federal Trade Commission were likely to open investigations.At least one state
column4: Massachusetts
column5: is also seeking more information from Yahoo about the breach
column6: a spokesperson for the state's attorney general told Reuters on Monday. Yahoo has so far not provided a clear
column7: detailed timeline about when it was made aware of the breach announced Thursday.

column1: Cyber security services firm Stroz Friedberg has been hired by Yahoo to help investigate the breach
column2: firm spokeswoman Carolyn Vadino said. The FBI is also investigating the hack
column3: which Yahoo has blamed on a ""state-sponsored actor"" although the company has not provided technical information to support that claim. (Reporting by Dustin Volz in Washington; Additional reporting by Jim Finkle in Boston; Editing by Cynthia Osterman and Mary Milliken)"	['Warner']	[]
